400: Bad Request - The request is malformed or missing required data.
401: Unauthorized - Authentication is required and has failed or has not yet been provided.
403: Forbidden - The request is valid but the client does not have permission to access the resource.
404: Not Found - The requested resource could not be found.
405: Method Not Allowed - The HTTP method is not supported for the requested resource.
406: Not Acceptable - The server cannot produce a response matching the Accept headers.
408: Request Timeout - The server timed out waiting for the request.
409: Conflict - The request could not be completed due to a conflict with the current state of the resource (e.g., duplicate entity or version conflict).
410: Gone - The resource is no longer available and has been permanently removed.
412: Precondition Failed - A condition in the request headers evaluated to false (e.g., ETag mismatch).
413: Payload Too Large - The request body is larger than the server is willing or able to process.
415: Unsupported Media Type - The server does not support the media type sent in the request.
422: Unprocessable Entity - The request is well-formed but contains semantic errors (validation failed, business rules violated).
423: Locked - The resource is locked and cannot be modified.
424: Failed Dependency - The request failed because a dependent action failed.
429: Too Many Requests - Rate limiting exceeded; too many requests in a given time window.
500: Internal Server Error - Generic unexpected error on the server.
501: Not Implemented - The server does not support the functionality required to fulfill the request.
502: Bad Gateway - The upstream server returned an invalid response.
503: Service Unavailable - The server is overloaded or down for maintenance.
504: Gateway Timeout - The upstream server failed to send a request in time.
507: Insufficient Storage - The server cannot store the representation needed to complete the request.
508: Loop Detected - The server detected an infinite loop while processing the request.
